pli-tv-kd8:13.1.0: 16. The instruction on the three robes
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.1: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Vesālī.
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.2: On the road between Rājagaha and Vesālī the Buddha saw a number of monks walking along, loaded up with robes on their heads, shoulders, and hips. He thought,
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.3: “These foolish men have turned to an abundance in robes too readily.
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.4: Let me set a limit on robes for the monks.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.1: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Vesālī, where he stayed at the Gotamaka Shrine.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.2: At that time it was midwinter, when the days are cold and the snow is falling. The Buddha sat outside at night without being cold, wearing only one robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.3: Becoming cold at the end of the first part of the night, he put on a second robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.4: Becoming cold once again at the end of the middle part of the night, he put on a third robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.5: At the end of the last part of the night, when the sky was flaring up at dawn, he became cold once more. Putting on a fourth robe, he was fine.
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.1: He thought, “Even those on this spiritual path who come from good families, who are sensitive to the cold and fear the cold, are able to get by with three robes.
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.2: Let me set a limit on robes for the monks. Let me allow them three robes.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks.

pli-tv-kd8:15.8.3: This is why I wish to give meals to the newly arrived monks for as long as I live.

pli-tv-kd8:16.2.2: For those who go to sleep absentminded and heedless, semen is emitted while dreaming.

pli-tv-kd8:16.3.1: “There are these five disadvantages in going to sleep absentminded and heedless:

pli-tv-kd8:16.3.4: And there are these five benefits in going to sleep mindful and heedful:
pli-tv-kd8:16.3.5: you sleep well; you wake up feeling good; you don’t have nightmares; the gods guard you; and you don’t emit semen.
pli-tv-kd8:16.3.7: And, monks, I allow a sitting mat to protect the body, the robes, and the furniture.”

pli-tv-kd8:26.1.0: 23. The account of the one who was sick
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.1: On one occasion there was a monk who had dysentery
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.2: who was lying in his own feces and urine.
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.3: Just then, as the Buddha was walking about the dwellings with Venerable Ānanda as his attendant, he came to the dwelling of this monk.
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.4: When he saw his condition, he went up to him and said,
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.10: “Because I don’t do anything for them.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.2: “Go and get some water, Ānanda. Let’s give him a wash.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.3: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he did just that.
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.4: And so the Buddha poured the water,
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.6: Then, the Buddha lifting him by the head
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.7: and Ānanda by the feet, they lay him on a bed.

pli-tv-kd8:26.3.2: “Is there a sick monk in that dwelling?”
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.9: “Because he doesn’t do anything for us.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.11: “Monks, you have no mother or father to nurse you.

pli-tv-kd8:26.3.13: Whoever would nurse me should nurse one who is sick.

pli-tv-kd8:26.4.13: If you have none of these, the Sangha should nurse you.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.14: If you don’t nurse one who is sick, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd8:26.5.1: “A sick person who has five qualities is hard to nurse:
pli-tv-kd8:26.5.2: they do what’s detrimental for curing the sickness; they don’t know the right amount in what’s beneficial; they don’t take their medicine; they don’t accurately describe the state of their illness—whether it’s getting worse, better, or remaining the same—to the one who’s nursing them and wishing them well; they’re unable to bear up with bodily feelings that are painful, severe, sharp, and life-threatening.
pli-tv-kd8:26.6.1: A sick person who has five qualities is easy to nurse:
pli-tv-kd8:26.6.2: they do what’s beneficial for curing the sickness; they know the right amount in what’s beneficial; they take their medicine; they accurately describe the state of their illness—whether it’s getting worse, better, or remaining the same—to the one who’s nursing them and wishing them well; they’re able to bear up with bodily feelings that are painful, severe, sharp, and life-threatening.
pli-tv-kd8:26.7.1: An attendant who has five qualities is unsuited to nurse the sick:
pli-tv-kd8:26.7.2: they’re incapable of preparing medicine; not knowing what’s beneficial and what’s harmful, they bring what’s harmful and remove what’s beneficial; they nurse the sick for the sake of worldly gain, not with a mind of kindness; they’re disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they’re incapable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a Dhamma talk from time to time.
pli-tv-kd8:26.8.1: An attendant who has five qualities is suited to nurse the sick:
pli-tv-kd8:26.8.2: they’re capable of preparing medicine; knowing what’s beneficial and what’s harmful, they remove what’s harmful and bring what’s beneficial; they nurse the sick with a mind of kindness, not for the sake of worldly gain; they’re not disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they’re capable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a Dhamma talk from time to time.”

pli-tv-kd8:28.1.0: 25. Discussion of the prohibition against nakedness
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.1: On one occasion a naked monk went to the Buddha and said,
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.2: “In many ways, Sir, you praise fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.3: Being naked leads to all those things.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.4: It would be good if you allowed nakedness for the monks.”
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.6: “Foolish man, it’s not suitable, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.7: How can you undertake the practice of nakedness, as do the monastics of other religions?
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.10: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.11: “You shouldn’t undertake the practice of nakedness, as do the monastics of other religions.

pli-tv-kd8:32.1.3: Someone gives within a monastery zone:
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.4: it should be shared out to all the monks within that zone.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.5: Someone gives to a recipient who has made an agreement:
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.6: when a number of monasteries have the same gains, then when it’s given in one monastery, it’s given to all.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.7: Someone gives where alms are prepared: someone gives where the Sangha is regularly working.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.8: Someone gives to the Sangha: it’s to be shared out to the present Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.9: Someone gives to both Sanghas: even when there are many monks and just a single nun, she should be given half; even when there are many nuns and just a single monk, he should be given half.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.10: Someone gives to a sangha that has completed the rainy-season residence: it’s to be shared out to the monks who have completed the rains residence in that monastery.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.11: Someone gives according to a specification: relating to rice porridge, a meal, fresh food, robe-cloth, a dwelling, or medicine.
